title: After COP30, Indigenous advocates celebrate gains while warning of unfinished work
description:
The COP30 climate conference in Belém, billed as the “Indigenous COP,” was defined by the organized presence of Indigenous activists, who staged protests and demanded inclusion in negotiations. Their advocacy led to tangible successes, notably Brazil’s promise to demarcate more Indigenous lands and the U.N.’s formal recognition of Indigenous rights, including Free, Prior, and Informed Consent, in the Just Transition Work Programme.

Despite these gains, Indigenous advocates were profoundly disappointed by the ultimate failure of U.N. member states to commit to a specific plan to stop relying on fossil fuels, with oil-rich nations watering down the final text. Leaders affirmed that the crucial fight for climate justice and land rights will continue through grassroots resistance, legal action, and future international forums, extending beyond the U.N. conference halls.
